text: [Music]
on the international stage Vladimir
Putin has been center stage in 2016 and
today he shared his view of the world
with the world's media putting a
question to the president isn't easy
when there are a thousand of you and
just one of him but he agreed to take my
question mr. president your country has
been accused of state-sponsored hacking
with the aim of influencing the results
of the u.s. presidential election and
President Obama revealed that he told
you personally to cut it out so what did
you tell him in response
yaaaaagghh and then you go or don't the
President refused to say dismissing all
the talk of hacking as sour grapes from
the Democratic Party but English is that
an effing they issued in our divemaster
Anya the losing side always tries to
pass the buck they would be better to
look for the problems among themselves
Russia said President Putin was
modernizing its nuclear missile
potential but he claimed he wasn't
worried by Donald Trump's tweet
yesterday pledging to boost America's
nuclear capability are you not concerned
though that there is a danger of a new
arms race if America is talking about
boosting its nuclear arsenal but nobody
really knows the basis for a new arms
race was there already after us pulled
out of the anti-ballistic missile treaty
and started to create a missile shield
so either we had to build our own show
or as we doing develop weapons to
penetrate this but this wasn't our
choice Vladimir Putin made it clear
today that if there is to be a new arms
race that won't be Russia's fault
and he delivered a defiant message that
Russia is stronger than any potential
aggressor but tough talk doesn't solve
domestic problems the Russian economy is
struggling not just because of sanctions
low oil prices have hit hard and economy
reliance on exporting energy
this year Russia has been flexing its
muscles it wants to be seen as a global
power but if President Putin doesn't
mend the cracks in the economy he'll be
building a superpower on thin ice Steve
Rosenberg BBC news Moscow
